title:
The Role of Adiposity in Cardiometabolic Traits: A
Mendelian Randomization Analysis
author: Fall
author_address: Molecular Epidemiology and Science for Life Laboratory, Department of Medical Sciences, Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cardiometabolic traits
rationale: The association between adiposity and cardiometabolic traits is well known from epidemiological studies. Whilst the causal relationship is clear for some of these traits, for others it is not.
outcome_definition: Systolic blood pressure ≥140, diastolic blood pressure ≥90, or on anti-hypertensive treatment
exposure_genotyping_dataset: Whenever rs9939609 was not genotyped directly, we used either (i) the HapMap II CEU (European) reference panel–imputed genetic information from genome-wide association studies (http://hapmap.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/downloads/genotypes/2008-10_phaseII/) for rs9939609 (n = 5) or (ii) genotype information from a predefined list of proxies that are in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs9939609 (n = 10, r2>0.9; Table S3)
analysis_software: Varied by cohort but  at least one cohort used PLINK, R, SPSS, STATA
limitations_overall: The limitations of our study are tied to the validity of the assumptions underlying causal interpretation within MR studies.
limitations_pleiotropy: the precise mechanism of the FTO polymorphisms is still unclear, and potential pleiotropy cannot completely be ruled out
limitations_population_stratification: all studies included only individuals of European ancestry. Hence, bias from population stratification is deemed unlikely
limitations_statistical_power: Post hoc power calculation showed that for the binary traits with non-significant IVs (CHD, ischemic stroke, and all-cause stroke), we had an 80% chance of detecting an IV estimator odds ratio (OR) of 1.08–1.09/BMI unit or higher, and a 95% chance of detecting an OR of 1.13–1.15/BMI unit or higher.

title: Causal association of body mass index with hypertension using a Mendelian randomization design
author: Lee
author_address: Department of Preventive Medicine, Seoul National University College of Medicine, 103 Daehakro, Jongrogu, Seoul 110-744, Republic of Korea
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on hypertension
rationale: Observational studies have shown that obesity is a major risk factor for hypertension, but unmeasured confounding factors may exist.
outcome_definition: Defined as SBP >= 140 or DBP >=90mmHg and taking antihypertensive drugs during the 10-year follow up
outcome_population: Koren ancestry - Ansan/Ansung population from KOGES
exposure_population: Koren ancestry - Ansan/Ansung population from KOGES
exposure_covariates_model: Despite discussing the MR methodology, they only show the results in a figure that doesn't include the effect estimates... What I can extract is the analyses where they performed direct G-D association in 4 models - (1) unadjusted; (2) adjusted for age and sex; (3) adjusted for age, sex, area (i.e., Ansan or Ansung), education, smoking and education; and (4) further adjusted for BMI. (I've just presented the unadjusted one here)
exposure_independence: some SNPs were found to be in linkage disequilibrium so they selected one representative SNP from closely linked SNPs based on the estimated size of the main genetic analysis results or significance in previous studies
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Note: they do an IV analysis but ONLY PRESENT THE P-VALUES. They present a figure with the IV analyses results but they don't present the actual odds ratios, just the P-values and just that they range between 1.13-1.26. Hence, why I've just presented the direct G-D results. We could probably calculate the IV analyses but would be good to get these somehow.
IV_strength: They just tested the association in the sample and in the discussion (not mentioned anywhere else), authors say that F-statistics ranged between 52.7-125.3 with all GRSs).
analysis_software: SAS version 9.3, plink version 1.08 and R version 3.1.0.
exposure_units: 1 SD in the BMI GRS (they do an IV analysis but don't present the actual ORs, just the p-values and the results in a figure.
limitations_overall: They do not present MR estimates outside of a figure from which estimates can not be retrieved. They additionally talk about validity and power: This difference might be due to the inclusion of additional marginally significant SNPs, which would reduce the strength and precision of a SNP-exposure association. First, we built the BMI GRS based only on common variants, so we were unable to assess the potential contribution of rare  variants. Second, this study did not include any subjects aged ≥70 years or <40 years, so these results may not be generalizable to populations of different ages. Third, this study examined the causal effect of obesity on BP, but we could not test the impact of acute changes.
limitations_pleiotropy: The rs9939609 SNP on the FTO gene has no known pleiotropy. However, the other SNPs were not validated to exclude pleiotropy.
limitations_population_stratification: Results may not be generalizable populations of different ethnicities because we used a cohort composed only of Koreans.
notes: Also something to mention is that, in the weighted GRS, I'm pretty sure (but it's not clear) that they use the weightings form the same sample (i.e., they did a linear regression of the SNPs on BMI in their sample, they took the beta coefficients from that linear regression and then used those beta coefficients to weight their GRS in the same sample) so overfitting is a problem here if that is the case. Additionally, It's really unclear but it says that they selected 32 SNPs based on linear regression (presumably in their study but not stated explictly), then they created 3 GRSs for BMI: one with the 2 SNPs that had been reported previously, one with the 4 SNPs that reached a pvalue threshold of 5x10e-6 and one with 6 SNPs that reached a pvalue threshold of 5x10-5

title: Causal association of body mass index with hypertension using a Mendelian randomization design
author: Lee
author_address: Department of Preventive Medicine, Seoul National University College of Medicine, 103 Daehakro, Jongrogu, Seoul 110-744, Republic of Korea
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on hypertension

outcome_population: Koren ancestry - Ansan/Ansung population from KOGES
exposure_population:
Authors selected 32 SNPs associated with BMI at a liberal p-value of 1x10-5 but doesn't say where these were obtained. Suggests they were just found in KOGES? Among the 32, 2 were previously reported (citing Cho YS, Go MJ, Kim YJ, et al. A large-scale genome-wide association
study of Asian populations uncovers genetic factors influencing eight
quantitative traits. Nat Genet 2009;41:527–34). But some were in high LD (D'>=0.9) so they chose 1 representative SNP from the closely linked SNPs based on estimate size of genetic analyses results or significance in previous studies. Then they constructed 6 GRSs.
exposure_covariates_model: Despite discussing the MR methodology, they only show the results in a figure that doesn't include the effect estimates... What I can extract is the analyses where they performed direct G-D association in 4 models - (1) unadjusted; (2) adjusted for age and sex; (3) adjusted for age, sex, area (i.e., Ansan or Ansung), education, smoking and education; and (4) further adjusted for BMI. (I've just presented the unadjusted one here)
exposure_independence: some SNPs were found to be in linkage disequilibrium so they selected one representative SNP from closely linked SNPs based on the estimated size of the main genetic analysis results or significance in previous studies
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Note: they do an IV analysis but ONLY PRESENT THE P-VALUES. They present a figure with the IV analyses results but they don't present the actual odds ratios, just the P-values and just that they range between 1.13-1.26. Hence, why I've just presented the direct G-D results. We could probably calculate the IV analyses but would be good to get these somehow.
IV_strength: They just tested the association in the sample and in the discussion (not mentioned anywhere else), authors say that F-statistics ranged between 52.7-125.3 with all GRSs).
analysis_software: SAS version 9.3, plink version 1.08 and R version 3.1.0.
exposure_units: 1 SD in the BMI GRS (they do an IV analysis but don't present the actual ORs, just the p-values and the results in a figure.
limitations_overall: They do not present MR estimates outside of a figure from which estimates can not be retrieved. They additionally talk about validity and power: This difference might be due to the inclusion of additional marginally significant SNPs, which would reduce the strength and precision of a SNP-exposure association. First, we built the BMI GRS based only on common variants, so we were unable to assess the potential contribution of rare  variants. Second, this study did not include any subjects aged ≥70 years or <40 years, so these results may not be generalizable to populations of different ages. Third, this study examined the causal effect of obesity on BP, but we could not test the impact of acute changes.
limitations_pleiotropy: The rs9939609 SNP on the FTO gene has no known pleiotropy. However, the other SNPs were not validated to exclude pleiotropy.
limitations_population_stratification: Results may not be generalizable populations of different ethnicities because we used a cohort composed only of Koreans.
notes: Also something to mention is that, in the weighted GRS, I'm pretty sure (but it's not clear) that they use the weightings form the same sample (i.e., they did a linear regression of the SNPs on BMI in their sample, they took the beta coefficients from that linear regression and then used those beta coefficients to weight their GRS in the same sample) so overfitting is a problem here if that is the case. title: Association of Body Mass Index With Cardiometabolic Disease in the UK Biobank
author: Lyall
author_address: Institute of Health and Wellbeing, University of Glasgow, 1 Lilybank Gardens, Glasgow G12 8RZ, Scotland
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cardiometabolic diseases/traits
rationale: Higher body mass index (BMI) is a risk factor for cardiometabolic disease; however, the underlying causal associations remain unclear.
outcome_definition: Participants were asked whether their physician had diagnosed them with hypertension. Participants were excluded if they had said "prefer not to answer"
exposure_age: Age range in Locke et al paper is 11-108
exposure_covariates_model: assessment centre, age, sex, genetic batch effect, array and stratification with 10 principal components
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Consistent with main analysis: Note that they said that they visually looked for outliers on the snp-exposure/snp-outcome scatter plot to see if there were any outliers. They said there was one for each of t2d and both blood pressure. However "results were unchanged when these outliers were removed and, for simplicity, we report estimates derived using all 93 SNPs"
multiple_testing: Yes - the authors stated "All statistical tests were 2-sided and P<0.01 was chosen as we had multiple outcomes; formal correction for type 1 error can be overly conservative when testing intercorrelated outcomes" but they don't show any correlations between outcomes or justify the choice of 0.01 any further than that statement
limitations_overall: We found a small but significant correlation between the PGR score and higher rates of smoking, alcohol intake, and Townsend deprivation scores and thus made additional adjustments for these factors in our analyses, which did notalter the estimates we obtained.
limitations_pleiotropy: Whether these associations represent vertical or horizontal pleiotropy remains unknown. The present sample also lacks data on a complete repertoire of potential mediators, such as lipid traits and glucose levels; these data will be available in the full UK Biobank in the next few years.
limitations_population_stratification: There may be a degree of selection bias in the sense that less physically and cognitively impaired individuals responded to theUKBiobank invitation and attended the assessment. The UK Biobank cohort is representative of the UK population in terms of some characteristics, such as age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation, but not necessarily all (eg,someparticipants are less likely tosmoke and drink alcohol regularly).
limitations_statistical_power: Because MR-Egger is inherently more conservative, potentially meaningful causal associations might not be identified (type II error). Furthermore, this approach may be inadequately powered to detect pleiotropy when it is present.
notes: Note: it's unclear how many individuals were used as controls, as the authors only state the number of cases and not the number of controls or not how many individuals overlapped between the four binary outcomes (i.e., stroke, CHD, hypertension and T2D). One note is that they state that they used 97 variants from the study of 339224 individuals of EUROPEAN descent. So actually unclear as to whether they used the European adults one or the all ancestries results. Note that the authors also did an adjusted model for townsend deprivation score, smoking and alcohol.  The results didn't really change when adding these (the betas attenuated slightly with some and inflated in others but confidence intervals all overlapped).
